title: Wednesday, 25th January, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:01am

Hi!

PM11:01am

We appreciate you too Otter

PM11:02am

Have a pic for today

11:01 am
PM11:02am

PM11:02am

Vijay Mallya

PM11:02am

Looks like he's getting shipped back to India pretty soon

11:02 am
PM11:02am

But must confess I've never quite understood the charges against him

PM11:03am

Well, I know he's generally outrageous

PM11:03am

Or was

11:03 am
PM11:03am

But the financial charges against him...bit baffling

PM11:03am

But I guess the Indian authorities know what they are doing

PM11:03am

https://www.ft.com...-8405-9e5580d6e5fb

11:03 am
undefined
PM11:04am

I thought for a period yesterday that Trump had lost control of his twitter account. Seized by adults.

PM11:04am

Luckily I was wrong

11:04 am
PM11:05am

But won't spam this chat

PM11:05am

It's ok Bryce

BE11:05am

Thumbs upTeeth smile

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Let's get on with market stuff

undefined
BE11:05am

If we must.

11:05 am
BE11:06am

So, where to start? We're flat-ish again, at least according to the index.

BE11:06am

FTSE up 0.2% at 7165

BE11:06am

Everything quite stable really, Sterling, oil, whatever, so we can head direct into corporate.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Where there's the usual collection of rubbish updates from companies habituated into giving rubbish updates.

Restaurant Group PLC (RTN:LSE): Last: 310.75, down 35.35 (-10.21%), High: 330.10, Low: 301.70, Volume: 4.57m
PM11:08am

This is a "post close" statement -- which you dont see very often

11:08 am
PM11:08am

http://www.investe...1701250700050079V/

PM11:08am

Quite funny tho in how dire it is

BE11:08am

It's the usual story really. The one we've told countless times.

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Actually Bryce your analysis of this has been spot on

PM11:09am

Albeit repetitive

PM11:09am

But it bears repeating!

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Indeed. That analysis being: Restaurant Group threw too much cash outside its niche of trapped customers (airports, cinemas, etc) and into retail. Retail footfall collapsed and barriers to entry weren't big enough as malls shoved more space to "leisure", where there was a flood of PE money trying to establish franchises.

BE11:11am

Along with the usual crazy lone punters willing to chuck their life savings up the wall on running a trattoria.

BE11:11am

Anyway, today's statement looks fine-ish but it's the exit rate that's the problem.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Suggesting things are going to get worse before they get better.

PM11:12am

Fine-ish?? I know this is a known mess but...

PM11:12am

As presented at our Interim results, we have started price and menu trials across Frankie & Benny's, which confirm that substantial price and proposition changes are required. Our strategic review of our other Leisure brands has revealed a need for similarly significant change.

11:12 am
PM11:12am

That's pretty damn bleak

PM11:13am

It's like 'we need to scrap what we are doing entirely and start again'

BE11:13am

Okay, by "fine-ish" I meant "it's a mess but management have a plan of sorts to fix things". What today does is move the starting line back considerably.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Deutsche incoming.

BE11:13am

The Restaurant Group expects 0.9% revenue growth in FY16E (consensus +1%, DB -1%), with LFL sales down 3.9%, (consensus -3.5%; DB -3% and compared to -3.7% in first 34 weeks of FY16E). The trend for LFL sales remains weak, with LFL sales falling 5.9% in 4Q16. The Restaurant Group expects results to be in line with the £74m-£80m guidance (consensus £75.4m; DB £74.8m). We expect consensus estimates for FY17E to fall 5-10% to reflect the ongoing weak LFL sales performance.

BE11:14am

RTN expects trading to remain difficult until the end of FY17E with "substantial price and proposition changes required" not only for Frankie & Benny's but other formats too. RTN closed 37 sites and opened 24 In FY16. The new CEO will update the market with the transformation plan at the final results on March 9.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

The Restaurant Group stands on a 14.0x PE for FY17E (7.1x EV/EBITDA), falling to 13.2x in FY18E (6.6x EV/EBITDA) using our current forecasts. Our 290p price target is DCF based.

BE11:14am

FOURTEEN TIMES! FOR THIS!

BE11:14am

(not investment advice)

11:14 am
BE11:15am

We are cautious on the UK Pubs & Restaurants sector. Our view is based on: 1) multiple cost headwinds which have already depressed growth (and flagged by the company again today); and, 2) concern that an unclear economic outlook may undermine UK consumer confidence and spending, in turn hitting sector revenues.

BE11:15am

The arrival of a new CEO with material multi-site retail experience is a potential significant catalyst for The Restaurant Group. However, we see multiple threats to RTN’s rating and earnings: 1) Trading weakness in the core Frankie & Benny’s format; 2) Ongoing rollout despite format underperformance; 3) Increased competition in historic high barrier to entry leisure/retail parks; 4) Cost to regain lapsed customers; 5) Cost inflation (wages, business rates).

BE11:16am

(@OJatHome: UBS upgrade.)

11:16 am
BE11:16am

But let's hear from some buyers. Canaccord.

PM11:16am

ok

BE11:16am

We are cutting our EPS forecasts by 2.9% for FY16E, by a swingeing 25.5% for FY17E and by 17% for FY18E. We reiterate our view that major brand Frankie & Benny’s is not broken, that it is fixable and that the share price does not fully reflect the upside potential of the recovery story. We would expect the material signs of recovery to become evident from 2H17.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

Now the serious work starts in earnest for the new management team: 37 worst performing sites have been closed, changes have been made below just board level and price and menu trials have started. Some old favourites (chicken pasta) have returned to the menu and the fixed price (£10.95) lunch menu has been restored. It's a start.

BE11:17am

"chicken pasta" .... Why didn't anyone think of that earlier?

BE11:17am

Accepting our reasonable assumptions for other parts of the business and a negative value of £39m for the disposal restaurants, then the core Frankie & Benny’s business is valued at just 3.7x EBITDA or just £0.8m/site at the current share price. We think this is too low and our 450p (was 545p) share price target assumes a valuation of 8.0x EBITDA, or £2.5m per site based on our FY17 forecasts (we have rolled forward 12 months).

11:17 am
BE11:17am

And Liberum.

BE11:18am

The softer exit run-rate from Q4 into Fy17E is disappointing and has led us to cut our numbers today. The group is about to enter a transformational year where the focus will be on restoring the groups value credentials and putting its offer at the heart of the family eating out circuit. The new management will for the first time at the prelims March 9 lay out their vision of the future. The work concluded by OC&C and our detailed industry analysis concludes the brands are not broken and there are identifiable remedial actions. It is with optimism that we feel the group may have passed the nadir in trading, cash flow remains strong and with negligible debt, the group has the firepower to execute a number of strategies. We see value in the shares and remain Buy

BE11:18am

"restoring the groups value credentials and putting its offer at the heart of the family eating out circuit" ... give me strength.

11:18 am
PM11:18am

I think we need to know what this chicken pasta looks like

PM11:18am

PM11:18am

Actually, could have been worse

11:18 am
BE11:18am

........... Pasta, chips and pizza!

BE11:19am

That's quite a lot of carb.

PM11:19am

Teeth smile

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Anyway, here's what Liberum wants to do.

PM11:19am

I feel fat just looking at it

BE11:19am

Cut the tail more aggressively: The site closures and impairments announced at the interims in Sep-16 could be the first stage of estate rationalisation. We think there is an opportunity to create a more solid base on which to grow. Hence we have factored in a further 15 sites to close in FY17E, above the 37 closed in FY16E,
Re-introducing the value and pricing proposition: As has been the case up until the change in the August 2015 menu, the value proposition at Frankie & Benny has been very strong. Our bespoke pricing work has revealed that there has not been a systemic rise in prices over the years but it has been one single menu change which has negatively impacted the value proposition. The figures below show that when we compared the Jun-15 menu against the Oct-13 Frankie & Benny menu it appears there was greater value with 94% of its menu priced at £15 or lower compared to 91% for the Oct-2013 menu. This proves our point that post the Aug-15 menu change the proposition changed for the worse highlighting this one change as the cause for the severe LFL declines.
Returning the menu to its core: There was also a total of 41 menu items removed from the Jun-15 menu, replaced by 26 new items in Aug-15. This means that a total of 67 changes out of 79 main menu items were made in the August 2015 menu. The average price of an adult main meal rose c.17% across the broad spectrum of the menu.

11:19 am
PM11:19am

Returning the menu to its core? Wot?

BE11:20am

I don't know. But Liberum also has a great chart of Frankie & Benny's pricing structure .....

BE11:20am

11:20 am
BE11:20am

.... which looks quite like its customers.

PM11:20am

laughing too much to type

BE11:20am

Anyway, I think we're done here. We'll annoy someone soon.

11:20 am
undefined
BE11:20am

Onto other stuff, then.

BE11:21am

Sellside, for instance.

11:20 am
Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 193.10, down 6.25 (-3.14%), High: 198.00, Low: 192.80, Volume: 48.48m
PM11:21am

if we must

BE11:21am

Merrill downgrade.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

BE11:21am

BE11:22am

That line about ruling out JVs is interesting, as the consensus at the moment seems to be that Vodafone will replicate its Dutch model in other problem markets.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

As in, the UK, Germany and probably Ireland.

BE11:23am

Merrill's also cautious on the idea of fixing India with a JV with Idea.

BE11:24am

May I draw your attention, too, to that EPS downgrade for 2017.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

As in, minus 358%.

undefined
BE11:25am

And since we mention Liberty ......

11:25 am
BE11:25am

..... guess we have to mention this Evening Standard story yesterday.

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 209.24, down 0.064 (-0.03%), High: 211.30, Low: 205.50, Volume: 5.75m
BE11:25am

Which had the shares up more than 5% at one point.

11:25 am
PM11:25am

hmm

BE11:25am

http://www.standar...over-a3448306.html

BE11:25am

The word on the street is that major shareholders of ITV have been sounded out by tech giants Apple, Amazon and Netflix about a possible takeover.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

.... which street?

PM11:26am

Kensington High St I guess -- or has the Standard moved?

BE11:26am

I'm also a bit curious about the idea that three companies have sounded out ITV's "major shareholders" .....

11:26 am
BE11:26am

I mean, Blackrock has 6. But this is spread across multiple funds, none of which are above 3% individually.

BE11:27am

In fact, I'm pretty sure there's not a single fund manager that speaks for more than 2.something %+ of ITV.

BE11:27am

The only holder of size is Liberty.

11:27 am
PM11:27am

Image of Apple, Amazon and Netflix execs lined up outside L&G would be something

BE11:28am

Anyway, here's JP Morgan to ask, "why on earth would Apple, Amazon and Netflix want to buy a business that makes 70% of its revenue on free-to-air broadcasting?"

BE11:28am

Whilst news flow over a possible acquisition is not new, the article introduces a new set of potential acquirers: US OTT
names such as Netflix and Amazon with a potential offer at around 300p per share. None of the companies has responded to the article. We keep our view that ITV's content operations would be attractive to several potential buyers but find it hard to see the angle on broadcasting as large US OTT players are likely to focus on scripted content with limited usage for shows we believe.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Potential offer price of 300p speculated in the article. In this context, we estimate that ITV shares valued at the mentioned 300p would equate to 18.2x/17.2x P/E for 2017E/18E (vs our current estimates of 12.2x/11.5x respectively) and 13.5x/12.9x EV/EBITDA for 2017E/18E (vs 9.2x/8.7x currently). In a reverse SOTP and based on a 300p potential offer price, putting the Content business on 14x 2017E EV/EBITA, the Broadcasting business would trade at 17.5x, a 75% premium to the European TV sector trading on 10.0x EV/EBITA.

BE11:28am

We reiterate our OW rating on the stock. Despite ongoing concerns around Brexit, we see value in ITV at these levels and keep the name in our top picks in the FTA space (and as one of our key buys within Media & Internet overall). The shares trade on 12.2x 17E P/E on our estimates, offering several sources of upside potential and a solid dividend.

undefined
11:29 am
PM11:29am

So this Jackpotjoy thing is actually going to join the London market

PM11:30am

Backstory here: https://ftalphavil...ackpotjoy-show-up/

PM11:30am

Going for a standard listing, which is London's way of turning itself into Vancouver

11:30 am
PM11:30am

So this company came out with a prospectus last week

PM11:30am

But no financial adviser

PM11:31am

No bank involved

11:30 am
PM11:31am

Ever seen that?

PM11:31am

Anyway, the prospectus is here

PM11:31am

http://jackpotjoyp...nts/Prospectus.pdf

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:31am

http://www.investe...1701250803020500V/

PM11:31am

So we can do the necessary tombstone

11:31 am
PM11:31am

Jackpotjoy plc

+1 416 720 8150

Amanda Brewer, Vice President of Corporate Communications

Corporate Broker: Canaccord Genuity Limited

+44 (0)207 523 8000

Bruce Garrow

Emma Gabriel

Richard Andrews

Media Enquiries: Finsbury

+44 (0)207 251 3801

James Leviton

Andy Parnis

PM11:32am

We can also read the prospectus

PM11:32am

Well, part of it. It's rather long

11:32 am
PM11:32am

Rick factors alone run to 30 pages

PM11:32am

And include bits like this

PM11:32am

On 17 December 2015, Intertain was targeted by the Report published by a self-described short-seller,
Spruce Point Capital Management. The Report made various allegations regarding Intertain, including
with respect to its prior acquisitions and the prospects of its acquired businesses, including, in particular,
the Jackpotjoy Brands, accounting, financial presentation and financial disclosure concerns, Intertain’s
governance, various links between members of the Intertain board and senior management and related
parties, and Intertain’s then-current management incentive plan (the “Management Incentive Plan”).
Following the publication of the Report, the board of directors of Intertain (the “Intertain Board”)
appointed an independent committee composed of non-management directors David Danziger, Stan
Dunford and Mark Redmond (the “Independent Committee”), to investigate the allegations made in the
Report in conjunction with the Independent Committee’s independent advisors.
These allegations were thoroughly reviewed by the Independent Committee and its independent advisors
and Intertain announced the results of the Independent Committee’s investigations and certain other
matters in press releases dated 8 February 2016 and 22 February 2016. The Independent Committee
concluded that the allegations and suggestions made in the Report in relation to the quality and financial
performance of the underlying businesses of the Group were grossly erroneous and the Report’s claims in
respect of the quality and performance of the Group’s underlying businesses were wrong in every
material resp

11:33 am
PM11:33am

Actually, this is brilliant

PM11:33am

Following the conclusion of the Independent Committee’s review, and as a result of further review by the
Intertain Board, Intertain also announced that Keith Laslop, Intertain’s Chief Financial Officer, would be
relocating to a new senior operational management position at Intertain Bahamas and that a suitably
experienced interim Chief Financial Officer would be appointed thereafter. Following further review, on
1 September 2016 the Intertain Board determined that Mr. Laslop would remain as the Chief Financial
Officer of Intertain and become the Chief Financial Officer and a director of the Company.

PM11:33am

Decided the CFO was not fit for purpose and then decided he was

11:33 am
PM11:34am

And..

PM11:34am

The Independent Committee identified three such payments,
collectively aggregating approximately CAD $7.8 million, made to nominee corporations understood to
be controlled by Darren Rennick, the current president of Intertain Bahamas, with such monies being held
for the benefit of the third parties having provided such services. All parties to these arrangements
advised that the monies were held exclusively for the benefit of such third parties.

PM11:34am

You can google the name Darren Rennick yourself

11:34 am
PM11:35am

Don't really know what else to say here

PM11:35am

Without first running it by the lawyer

undefined
11:35 am
BE11:35am

..................... Yikes. Anyway ..................

BE11:35am

Knife catchers are out on the left in BT.

BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 305.83, up 2.83 (+0.93%), High: 309.75, Low: 297.80, Volume: 39.85m
11:35 am
PM11:36am

Yeah, noticed that

BE11:36am

Biggest ever fall yesterday.

BE11:36am

There are brokers suggesting you buy down here, but there's exclusively brokers who were also suggesting you should buy up there so ......

11:36 am
BE11:37am

Here's RBC suggesting you double down.

BE11:37am

We see BT's shock announcement as an opportunity to buy. BT Italia will be resolved, the public sector could be partly timing due to government changes, and the rest of the business is in good shape. BT is strategically very well positioned, is deleveraging (despite growing dividends) and can resolve the regulatory overhang.

BE11:37am

(1) BT Italia will ultimately be resolved. KPMG has almost finished its review and the issues do not affect other Global Services units. The £175m hit on EBITDA of c.£65m is unlikely to leave BT with a £100m loss each year as FY17 and FY18 include cost write-backs and BT will seek to turn the unit around.

2) Public sector could be partly timing. Management said the issues were probably due to the economy and Brexit, with departments not spending their budgets before their year ends, less decentralisation of budgets, and smaller renewals of big contracts. The comments appear to echo what other public-sector-facing business have said, eg, Carillion: "the pace of new order intake has slowed... due in part to the changes within UK Government Departments following the EU referendum result". We agree with our colleagues in business services that these changes in government and the uncertainty of Brexit appear to be delayed decision making rather than a permanent reduction in order flow.

3) Rest of the business appears OK. BT reports 3Q on Friday, but the rest of the business appears in decent health with strong mobile demand in corporate and SME (virgin territory to retail-focused EE), whole and ventures seeing an improving underlying trend and Openreach recording the highest-ever fibre broadband adds.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

(@Patience: that sounds a very difficult thing to prove objectively, but a very easy thing to claim anecdotally.)

BE11:38am

We use a discounted cash flow (DCF) and multiple-based SOTP to arrive at our ex-dividend price target of 475p. Our weighted cost of capital is 7.5% for BT with modest perpetual growth assumptions (1.0%). Our price target supports our Outperform rating.

PM11:38am

(Patience -- you take investment advice from Radio 4!)

11:38 am
BE11:38am

...... And Citi.

BE11:38am

BT saw £7.9bn wiped from its market value on 24 Jan after citing a higher than expected impact from the accounting review of its Italian operation and deteriorating UK public sector and international corporate businesses. We see the company's new targets as somewhat pessimistic, regard the reaction as overdone and retain our Buy rating but on a DCF based target price of 425p (from 460p), due to lower estimates. We leave our dividend forecasts unchanged, implying yields of 5.8% and 6.2% in FY18/19e respectively and allowing a combination of deleveraging and rising pension repair payments.

BE11:39am

On our new estimates BT trades on 10.6x and 10.1x OpFCF for FY18 and 19, respectively, vs the sector average of 13.3x and 12.2x. It trades on unlevered FCF yields of 6.7% and 8.3% compared to the sector on 5.4% and 6.2%.

11:39 am
PM11:39am

Interesting that they feel the divi is safe.

PM11:40am

At circa 6% yield

PM11:40am

You can see the superficial attraction

11:40 am
BE11:40am

You can. But for a rather aggressively put counterpoint, I turn once again to Saeed Baradar's of Louis Capital.

PM11:40am

Excellent

BE11:40am

**** PT CUT TO 250P - SELL INTO ANY DEAD CAT BOUNCE THIS WEEK - I am cutting my PT on BT from 300p to 250p this morning. The main reason is that the stock movement yesterday was mainly driven by weakening fundamentals on the "top line" only. The impact of a worsening "cost" situation driven by the high uneconomical "investment in content" is still not visible to the market and is not factored in the shares, in my view. As we move into 2017, and with the first round of bidding for European Champions League due in March 2017, I expect the focus to move more towards the analysis of the "returns" on these investments. With SKY likely to be emboldened by Fox's intended acquisition and with possibly a greater budget, BT will need to bid even more than the £897m bid of 3 years ago, in order to win the rights, in my view.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

**** UNACHIEVABLE BREAK-EVEN POINT IMPLIES THAT CONTENT INVESTMENT REMAINS A BOTTOMLESS PIT FOR BT - I calculate the break-even point of a BT TV sports customer at nearly £31.8/month. The argument that the break-even point of £31.8/m will decline in time as more subscribers join BT TV’s platform is absolutely valid but how much will the cost of acquiring the sports right inflate by? In the last EPL auction BT had to pay a premium of 30% over the price they had paid 3 years earlier. The European Championship/Europa league auctions are coming up and all indications are that the next EPL auctions are likely to increase significantly in value. That leaves us with two conclusions:

PM11:41am

I'm liking this chap

BE11:41am

** 1) BT has to continue to charge premium prices for its broadband service vis-à-vis Vodafone and others operators in order to underwrite its content (TV) costs. However with Vodafone now undercutting their broadband cost as they do not need to subsidize their mobile customers, BT has no option but to reduce prices or face losing customers once the contract terms end. In either case it will be difficult to see a longer term winning scenario or

** 2) BT refuses to renew or bid for any further football rights. In such a scenario BT will be back to square one, i.e. where it was before the launch of BT Sport and therefore will face the potential loss of its broadband customers especially at a time when other operators such as Virgin Media have upgraded the reach and the quality of their network. No winning scenario here either.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

[Skipping a bit]

BE11:42am

[Get on his email list yourself if you want the full thing]

BE11:42am

**** THE CONCLUSION IS CLEAR : Under the current pricing model and given the competitors positioning it is hard to justify how BT can make a long term economic return by investing in inflating sports rights.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

**** NEXT A DIVIDEND CUT: THE 15-20% DOWNGRADE IN FCF (£550m-£700m downgrade) removes all the safety net that BT had. Previously we had calculated that after Pension payments and share buy-backs BT will have around £2.3bn of FCF for next year. With dividends guided to increase by 10% per annum, by FY18/19 this implies a payment of £1.65bn. That leaves an FCF post FY18/19 of £2.3bn - £1.65bn = £650m for spectrum license costs, increases in unexpected content costs, etc. Today's downgrade of £550-700m removes all that safety net and hence any rise in content costs in the upcoming auctions will pressure the dividend from an organic perspective. Sure - BT can tap the debt markets to pay the dividend - but I don't think that investors will reward the company for that strategy! SELL.

BE11:42am

Dunno, Perhaps I just tend to instinctively agree with people who are shouting at me, but I'm more convinced of that take than the "value" ones above.

undefined
11:43 am
PM11:43am

Wh Smith top of the 250 board

PM11:43am

But it's the same story

PM11:43am

Gouging people at airports and train stations

11:43 am
PM11:44am

http://www.investe...1701250700050019V/

WH Smith PLC (SMWH:LSE): Last: 1,580, up 100 (+6.76%), High: 1,596, Low: 1,521, Volume: 424.27k
BE11:44am

With the Christmas kicker of book sales to people who buy one book a year.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

That's not me being snide. That's actual WH Smith data. Their customers buy on average one book a year.

BE11:45am

This year's novelty is "spoof books"

PM11:45am

Spoof books?

11:45 am
BE11:45am

As in, those "Ladybird Book of Hipsters" things.

PM11:46am

Ah, thought it was books on how to win at spoof (I claim to be quite good at that)

BE11:46am

No. They're the new adult colouring books -- suggesting that the customers buying one book a year are making bad choices even at that low ratio.

11:46 am
PM11:47am

BE11:47am

That's the chap. Otherwise, it's the usual stuff about filling the store with stationary and cutting out whatever category is dying fastest.

BE11:48am

Since the demise of CDs, WH Smith has been in a constant battle to find something to fill its own floorspace. And, amazingly, it's been winning.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Let me get some sellside.

BE11:48am

Deutsche.

BE11:48am

WH Smith reported healthy sales growth in the first 21 weeks of its financial year, ahead of our expectations. High Street was in line, with the changes to the stationery category helping to annualise its toughest comparatives since 2003. Travel, however, continued to surprise positively, with +5% like for likes. On our forecasts, which we upgrade c.1%, Travel represents 60% of group profits and offers a strong runway of growth for the future. The stock trades on a CY17E FCF of around 7% with, we believe, less macro risk than most UK retailers. Buy.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

(@WayneJ: I've heard worse ideas.)

BE11:49am

High Street delivered a peak performance which was in line with expectations. Like for likes were -3%, a touch ahead of our -4% forecast and against the strong ‘colour therapy’ comparatives from last year. Gross margins, we estimate, rose by c.90bps, supported by mix effects albeit there was a drag from reversing last year’s sales mix. With cost savings continue to flow through as expected and Post Office boosting margins, we expect High Street to deliver unchanged profits this year. Now its seasonal peak has passed, the risk profile is significantly lowered, and the focus is likely to move to Travel.

BE11:49am

Travel should represent 60% of group profits this year. At this early stage in the year, given its seasonal peak is during the summer, its strong sales performance (total +10%, LFL +5%) drives our forecast upgrades. The growth was strong across all channels, and our new divisional profit forecast of £93m (Figure 4) still assumes slower profit growth than last year despite the maturity of some of its international units. We think forecasts may prove conservative, though the seasonal peak is ahead of them in air (about half of divisional sales,

11:49 am
BE11:50am

WH Smith is debt free (including pension) and returns all of its free cash flow as dividends and buybacks. With a FCF yield of 7%, defensive qualities and growth potential, we rate the stock a Buy. It currently trades on CY17E P/E of 14.3x. Our DCF-driven target uses a WACC of 8.6% (RFR 4.5%, ERP 4.5%, beta 0.9x) and nominal TGR of +1.5%. The main downside risks are a downturn in passenger travel or that High Street cost and gross margin opportunities are insufficient to offset weakness in the printed news categories.

BE11:50am

BE11:56am

Which is UBS turning positive.

BE11:57am

We upgrade ASHM to a Buy, from a Neutral rating, as we believe the market has over-reacted to the impact a stronger US$ and rising US$ interest rates will have on EM debt and ASHM, where 90%+ of AUMs are in EM Debt. Our analysis shows EM debt has been able to generate healthy 8% annual returns in rising rate environments (vs. 11% in other periods) and we expect ASHM to report net inflows in the March 2017 quarter for the first time since 2014 and for these flows to improve through 2017 and 2018.

BE11:57am

Downgrades to Ashmore's ratings and price targets followed the company's disappointing Q4 2016 flow figures (US$700mn of outflows). We believe those outflows, which were concentrated in the 3-4 weeks following the US presidential election, were a knee-jerk reaction by investors to rising US$ interest rates, a steepening US$ yield curve and a strengthening US$. Since mid-December, inflows into EM debt products have rebounded and the value of the EM Bond Index has appreciated by 4%. As a result, we forecast US$2bn of inflows in 2017 and then US$4bn of inflows in 2018. At current valuations, the market is pricing in US$2-3bn of outflows in 2017.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Interesting bit .....

BE11:57am

Despite a common misconception, EM debt performance in the past has not been hindered by rising US$ interest rates or a strengthening US$. Looking at the rolling 12-month performance of EM debt vs. the 12-month change to US$ interest rates, there has been a positive correlation between US$ interest rate changes and the absolute and relative performance of EM debt.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Our upgrade on ASHM is counter-consensus as there is just one other broker with a Buy rating on the stock. That said, Ashmore is an excellent company with top-quality management, a rock-solid balance sheet (17% of its market cap in excess cash), a superior regulatory capital position, and is more immune to passives than peers. As a result, we believe the current share price is an attractive entry point. In addition, with a 5.7% dividend yield and significant cash position to protect that dividend, we argue this is a very attractive stock for dividend-focused investors.
